content: It's a sad commentary when citizens complain about noise from a base staffed with people willing to put their lives on the line to protect the complainers. I live in a small town between Westover AFB at Westover, MA and the commercial airport serving CT. So we have noise from military and civiian aircraft daily. Depending upon flight paths, some days we do not see or hear any aircraft except in the distance. Under the right weather conditions, we can hear aircraft engine noise rumbling through the valley. Naturally, some people who live closer to either station the noise is more of a problem to them. But at public hearings, I'm always amazed by people who bought a home located near either station and who are attending the meeting complaining about aircraft noise! Did they think because they moved into the area things would suddenly stop to ease their complaints about noise? Frankly, I love seeing the C5's and other military aircraft flying overhead...CH53's, UH60's, CH47's, you name it...it's great to know people are training to cover the backs of my family and friends. The commercial aircraft...that's great also...commerce, jobs, helping the local and state economy. I say to the cry babies in Virginia...move if you don't like the noise and quit wasting the taxpayers money, my money to cover their own stupidity. S/F Gordon

Did they think because they moved into the area things would suddenly stop to ease their complaints about noise? Frankly, I love seeing the C5's and other military aircraft flying overhead...CH53's, UH60's, CH47's, you name it...it's great to know people are training to cover the backs of my family and friends. The commercial aircraft...that's great also...commerce, jobs, helping the local and state economy. I say to the cry babies in Virginia...move if you don't like the noise and quit wasting the taxpayers money, my money to cover their own stupidity. S/F Gordon

title: Aircraft Noise

content: I have been in military and civil aviation for over forty years and it never ceases to amaze me, people knowingly purchase or rent a house near an airport that has existed for decades and then complain about the noise... If the sound of aircraft bothers you, then move!... The airport was there before you and if you bought there knowing the airport is there, you have no complaint... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
reply: I have been in military and civil aviation for over forty years and it never ceases to amaze me, people knowingly purchase or rent a house near an airport that has existed for decades and then complain about the noise... If the sound of aircraft bothers you, then move!... The airport was there before you and if you bought there knowing the airport is there, you have no complaint... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
title: Aircraft Noise

content: If you live within 5 miles or less of a base then it can get pretty loud. specially when they do training missions. When they fly low then it can get loud and shaky. It's cool to see some black hawks flying at high speed low over the houses but at 3am at night it can get annoying.
reply: If you live within 5 miles or less of a base then it can get pretty loud. specially when they do training missions. When they fly low then it can get loud and shaky. It's cool to see some black hawks flying at high speed low over the houses but at 3am at night it can get annoying.
title: Aircraft Noise

content: quote: Originally posted by world_king377: If you live within 5 miles or less of a base then it can get pretty loud. specially when they do training missions. When they fly low then it can get loud and shaky. It's cool to see some black hawks flying at high speed low over the houses but at 3am at night it can get annoying. Then you shouldn't live there... I live within fifteen miles of one military airfield and thirty-five from another... When the atmospherics are right, I get the rumble from aircraft on the line, when they are "turned" for maintenance, from the closest one and I get fly overs from both and there have been times late at night, when we've had CH-54s fly low, fast and blacked out, over our house, IT'S GREAT!... The cat dives for cover, the dogs go nuts, the windows rattle, the wife looks annoyed and I dive out the front door to get a look, GREAT!... I wish that I was a young man again and in that crew, I love it!... Dedicated crews, brilliantly trained and flying for the safety of the nation and my family, THANK YOU!... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
quote: Originally posted by world_king377: If you live within 5 miles or less of a base then it can get pretty loud. specially when they do training missions. content: Loud is going full military power in the "hush house" at NAS MCAS Miramar. The J-52P6 in the TA-4J was loud at military power. The J-52P8 in the A-4E was louder. But the J-52P408 in the A-4F superfox was off the charts!
reply: Loud is going full military power in the "hush house" at NAS MCAS Miramar. The J-52P6 in the TA-4J was loud at military power. The J-52P8 in the A-4E was louder. But the J-52P408 in the A-4F superfox was off the charts!

content: quote: Originally posted by BAGodbehere: It's not noise, it's the sound of Freedom. Great post! S/F Gordon, I grew up to the north of you in Portsmouth, NH. We had what was then Pease AFB, a SAC base with FB-111's and KC-135's flying in and out every single day. Man, I loved it as a kid and we were very close to the flight path...so close that on nights when the base had an alert, our windows shook. It was COOL! Don
quote: Originally posted by BAGodbehere: It's not noise, it's the sound of Freedom.

content: This is really wierd. My very first base I was so use to sleeping with the sound of F-4s and KC-135s running up that it didn't bother me at all. THEN, I was assigned to the missle field. Ever try to sleep when there is COMPLETE quiet!! Never thought I'd miss that sound but.... it took me quite a few weeks to be able to fall asleep. Really wierd!!
reply: This is really wierd. My very first base I was so use to sleeping with the sound of F-4s and KC-135s running up that it didn't bother me at all. THEN, I was assigned to the missle field. Ever try to sleep when there is COMPLETE quiet!! Never thought I'd miss that sound but.... it took me quite a few weeks to be able to fall asleep. Really wierd!!

Really wierd!! I don't think so. I use to sleep great when underway on a USCG cutter. The diesels running...noise, vibration, the swaying. Then when we'd be in port moored to the dock, I slept like crap. Don

title: Aircraft Noise

content: It does never cease to amaze me the whining some do. At Dover, people would move into houses and/or a trailer park just north of the perimeter fence, then complain when engines were run. What? Didn't think those 40 or so large aluminum clouds make noise? At McChord, we had quiet hours (2300 - 0600) except if the plane was scheduled for a mission, then we could get permission to run. However, the local press had a field day over it. One idiot found out the wing CC's phone number and published it. The base was originally well outside the center of population, but the area grew up around it. Some much for smart planning. In fct the only base I was at where people didn't complain was Loring and that ws because there were not very many people around to do so.
reply: It does never cease to amaze me the whining some do. At Dover, people would move into houses and/or a trailer park just north of the perimeter fence, then complain when engines were run. What? It's cool to see some black hawks flying at high speed low over the houses but at 3am at night it can get annoying. yea but i lived in the middle of a major city so I Dont complain about it i enjoy the fly by's but it does get annoying at times when they do flyby's at the dead of night. Then you shouldn't live there... I live within fifteen miles of one military airfield and thirty-five from another... When the atmospherics are right, I get the rumble from aircraft on the line, when they are "turned" for maintenance, from the closest one and I get fly overs from both and there have been times late at night, when we've had CH-54s fly low, fast and blacked out, over our house, IT'S GREAT!... The cat dives for cover, the dogs go nuts, the windows rattle, the wife looks annoyed and I dive out the front door to get a look, GREAT!... I wish that I was a young man again and in that crew, I love it!... Dedicated crews, brilliantly trained and flying for the safety of the nation and my family, THANK YOU!... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
title: Aircraft Noise

content: My snoring and my wife's coughing make more noise than any Aircraft I know.

title: Aircraft Noise

content: Loud is going full military power in the "hush house" at NAS MCAS Miramar. The J-52P6 in the TA-4J was loud at military power. The J-52P8 in the A-4E was louder. But the J-52P408 in the A-4F superfox was off the charts!
reply: Loud is going full military power in the "hush house" at NAS MCAS Miramar. The J-52P6 in the TA-4J was loud at military power. The J-52P8 in the A-4E was louder. But the J-52P408 in the A-4F superfox was off the charts!

content: quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: Loud is going full military power in the "hush house" at NAS MCAS Miramar. The J-52P6 in the TA-4J was loud at military power. The J-52P8 in the A-4E was louder. But the J-52P408 in the A-4F superfox was off the charts! scooter.. any worse then the F/A 18, a KC 135 or KC-10 with a full load of fuel? When the latter hit rotate they are at full military power! I use to play golf at NAS Cecil Field. An F/A 18 over the back nine would shake the grass on approach.

title: Aircraft Noise

content: quote: Originally posted by BAGodbehere: It's not noise, it's the sound of Freedom. Great post! S/F Gordon, I grew up to the north of you in Portsmouth, NH. We had what was then Pease AFB, a SAC base with FB-111's and KC-135's flying in and out every single day. Man, I loved it as a kid and we were very close to the flight path...so close that on nights when the base had an alert, our windows shook. It was COOL! Don
quote: Originally posted by BAGodbehere: It's not noise, it's the sound of Freedom.

Man, I loved it as a kid and we were very close to the flight path...so close that on nights when the base had an alert, our windows shook. It was COOL! Don

title: Aircraft Noise

content: This is really wierd. My very first base I was so use to sleeping with the sound of F-4s and KC-135s running up that it didn't bother me at all. THEN, I was assigned to the missle field. Ever try to sleep when there is COMPLETE quiet!! Never thought I'd miss that sound but.... it took me quite a few weeks to be able to fall asleep. Really wierd!!
reply: This is really wierd. My very first base I was so use to sleeping with the sound of F-4s and KC-135s running up that it didn't bother me at all. THEN, I was assigned to the missle field. Ever try to sleep when there is COMPLETE quiet!! Never thought I'd miss that sound but.... it took me quite a few weeks to be able to fall asleep. Really wierd!!
title: Aircraft Noise

content: quote: Originally posted by daddysoilder: This is really wierd. My very first base I was so use to sleeping with the sound of F-4s and KC-135s running up that it didn't bother me at all. THEN, I was assigned to the missle field. Ever try to sleep when there is COMPLETE quiet!! Never thought I'd miss that sound but.... it took me quite a few weeks to be able to fall asleep. Really wierd!! I don't think so. I use to sleep great when underway on a USCG cutter. The diesels running...noise, vibration, the swaying. Then when we'd be in port moored to the dock, I slept like crap. Don

title: Aircraft Noise

content: It does never cease to amaze me the whining some do. At Dover, people would move into houses and/or a trailer park just north of the perimeter fence, then complain when engines were run. What? Didn't think those 40 or so large aluminum clouds make noise? At McChord, we had quiet hours (2300 - 0600) except if the plane was scheduled for a mission, then we could get permission to run. However, the local press had a field day over it. One idiot found out the wing CC's phone number and published it. The base was originally well outside the center of population, but the area grew up around it. Some much for smart planning. In fct the only base I was at where people didn't complain was Loring and that ws because there were not very many people around to do so.
reply: It does never cease to amaze me the whining some do. At Dover, people would move into houses and/or a trailer park just north of the perimeter fence, then complain when engines were run. What? title: Aircraft Noise

content: It's a sad commentary when citizens complain about noise from a base staffed with people willing to put their lives on the line to protect the complainers. I live in a small town between Westover AFB at Westover, MA and the commercial airport serving CT. So we have noise from military and civiian aircraft daily. Depending upon flight paths, some days we do not see or hear any aircraft except in the distance. Under the right weather conditions, we can hear aircraft engine noise rumbling through the valley. Naturally, some people who live closer to either station the noise is more of a problem to them. But at public hearings, I'm always amazed by people who bought a home located near either station and who are attending the meeting complaining about aircraft noise! Did they think because they moved into the area things would suddenly stop to ease their complaints about noise? Frankly, I love seeing the C5's and other military aircraft flying overhead...CH53's, UH60's, CH47's, you name it...it's great to know people are training to cover the backs of my family and friends. The commercial aircraft...that's great also...commerce, jobs, helping the local and state economy. I say to the cry babies in Virginia...move if you don't like the noise and quit wasting the taxpayers money, my money to cover their own stupidity. S/F Gordon
reply: It's a sad commentary when citizens complain about noise from a base staffed with people willing to put their lives on the line to protect the complainers. Naturally, some people who live closer to either station the noise is more of a problem to them. But at public hearings, I'm always amazed by people who bought a home located near either station and who are attending the meeting complaining about aircraft noise! Did they think because they moved into the area things would suddenly stop to ease their complaints about noise? Frankly, I love seeing the C5's and other military aircraft flying overhead...CH53's, UH60's, CH47's, you name it...it's great to know people are training to cover the backs of my family and friends. The commercial aircraft...that's great also...commerce, jobs, helping the local and state economy. I say to the cry babies in Virginia...move if you don't like the noise and quit wasting the taxpayers money, my money to cover their own stupidity. S/F Gordon

title: Aircraft Noise

content: I have been in military and civil aviation for over forty years and it never ceases to amaze me, people knowingly purchase or rent a house near an airport that has existed for decades and then complain about the noise... If the sound of aircraft bothers you, then move!... The airport was there before you and if you bought there knowing the airport is there, you have no complaint... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
reply: I have been in military and civil aviation for over forty years and it never ceases to amaze me, people knowingly purchase or rent a house near an airport that has existed for decades and then complain about the noise... If the sound of aircraft bothers you, then move!... The airport was there before you and if you bought there knowing the airport is there, you have no complaint... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
title: Aircraft Noise

content: If you live within 5 miles or less of a base then it can get pretty loud. specially when they do training missions. When they fly low then it can get loud and shaky. It's cool to see some black hawks flying at high speed low over the houses but at 3am at night it can get annoying.
reply: If you live within 5 miles or less of a base then it can get pretty loud. specially when they do training missions. When they fly low then it can get loud and shaky. It's cool to see some black hawks flying at high speed low over the houses but at 3am at night it can get annoying.
title: Aircraft Noise

content: quote: Originally posted by world_king377: If you live within 5 miles or less of a base then it can get pretty loud. specially when they do training missions. When they fly low then it can get loud and shaky. It's cool to see some black hawks flying at high speed low over the houses but at 3am at night it can get annoying. Then you shouldn't live there... I live within fifteen miles of one military airfield and thirty-five from another... When the atmospherics are right, I get the rumble from aircraft on the line, when they are "turned" for maintenance, from the closest one and I get fly overs from both and there have been times late at night, when we've had CH-54s fly low, fast and blacked out, over our house, IT'S GREAT!... The cat dives for cover, the dogs go nuts, the windows rattle, the wife looks annoyed and I dive out the front door to get a look, GREAT!... I wish that I was a young man again and in that crew, I love it!... Dedicated crews, brilliantly trained and flying for the safety of the nation and my family, THANK YOU!... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

I love aircraft, their sights, sounds, smells and those that work and crew them... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
title: Aircraft Noise

content: My snoring and my wife's coughing make more noise than any Aircraft I know.
reply: My snoring and my wife's coughing make more noise than any Aircraft I know.
title: Aircraft Noise

content: Loud is going full military power in the "hush house" at NAS MCAS Miramar. The J-52P6 in the TA-4J was loud at military power. The J-52P8 in the A-4E was louder. But the J-52P408 in the A-4F superfox was off the charts!

content: quote: Originally posted by BAGodbehere: It's not noise, it's the sound of Freedom. Great post! S/F Gordon, I grew up to the north of you in Portsmouth, NH. We had what was then Pease AFB, a SAC base with FB-111's and KC-135's flying in and out every single day. Man, I loved it as a kid and we were very close to the flight path...so close that on nights when the base had an alert, our windows shook. It was COOL! Don

content: This is really wierd. My very first base I was so use to sleeping with the sound of F-4s and KC-135s running up that it didn't bother me at all. THEN, I was assigned to the missle field. Ever try to sleep when there is COMPLETE quiet!! Never thought I'd miss that sound but.... it took me quite a few weeks to be able to fall asleep. Really wierd!!
reply: This is really wierd. My very first base I was so use to sleeping with the sound of F-4s and KC-135s running up that it didn't bother me at all. THEN, I was assigned to the missle field. title: Aircraft Noise

content: It does never cease to amaze me the whining some do. At Dover, people would move into houses and/or a trailer park just north of the perimeter fence, then complain when engines were run. What? Didn't think those 40 or so large aluminum clouds make noise? At McChord, we had quiet hours (2300 - 0600) except if the plane was scheduled for a mission, then we could get permission to run. However, the local press had a field day over it. One idiot found out the wing CC's phone number and published it. The base was originally well outside the center of population, but the area grew up around it. Some much for smart planning. In fct the only base I was at where people didn't complain was Loring and that ws because there were not very many people around to do so.
